-na(r(a))/-nha(r(a))/-nya(r(a))Allomorphs of the nominaliser affix depend on the conjugation of the root to which it is added.The full form of the NMLSR (with final/ra/) is always used preceding case markers or derivational affixes (i) if the verb-root is monosyllabic; or (ii) if the case-marker consists of a single phoneme. Elsewhere, either the long form or the short form, which is identical to the PAST NON-INDIC inflection may be used. If the NMLSR suffix is word-final (i.e. if it takes -0 case inflection), it takes the full form with deletion of the final vowel. Non-inflecting verbs do not have a nominalised form; derivational affixes are added directly to the verb-root.

The portmanteau suffixes that encode agreement also indicate TAM, whereas only the realis suffixes vary for person and number. It should be noted however, that even in the realis, (depending on the verb class) only two or three opposing forms exist per category in (present or past): one for first or third person singular, occasionally one for the second person singular, and one for the remaining referents.
